0.user_question: Let $n$ be a positive integer.  What is the greatest possible value of $\gcd(n + 7, 2n + 1)$?
Let $n$ be a positive integer.  What is the greatest possible value of $\gcd(n + 7, 2n + 1)$?

ost_step.1: Let $d$ be any common divisor of $n + 7$ and $2n + 1$. Then $d$ divides both quantities since it is a common divisor. Thus, $d | [(2n + 1) - n - 7] = d|[n-6]$. Hence $d$ also divides $[n + 7-(n-6)]=13$. Conversely, every multiple of 13 is clearly a divisor of $n + 7$, so our goal reduces to finding what multiples of 13 maximize the second quantity.
ost_step.2: Note firstly that no matter how large you choose your chosen $n$, when divided into $2n+1$ leaves either one or zero as the residue class modulo 13 ($\{...,-14, -1,-2, ...\}$, $\{...,  3, 4, 5....\})$, showing us nothing about whether the maximum occurs before or not until comparing outcomes directly based upon larger ranges. But let’s start small! Consider just those integers up till say m=21; namely {1,...,21} For each term listed above observe carefully exactly which ones leave a nonzero result mod 13:$a\equiv b\pmod {m}\Leftrightarrow {\rm resclass}(a)\ne{\rmrescls}(b)\\{-14,\quad    -1,\quad     2,\quad    4,\quad      8,\quad       10\\}-13,\quad  -\infty ,\quad   -\infty,\quad-\infty,\quad-\infty,\quad  -\infty \\-12,\quad -11,\quad -7,\quad -5,\quad -3\\-11,\quad -10,\quad -6,\quad  -2,\quad  0

direct_answer.text: To solve this problem, let's use some algebra and properties related to Greatest Common Divisors (GCD): If $d$ is a common divisor of $n$ and $2n$, then indeed it must also divide $2n+1-n=n+1$. However, even though adding 7 wouldn't change anything regarding being relatively prime unless $d=-13$; otherwise, the new difference would still allow another potential shared divisor besides 13 i.e., 'the gcd'. 0.user_question: Let $n$ be a positive integer.  What is the greatest possible value of $\gcd(n + 7, 2n + 1)$?

1.subquestion: Suppose $d = \gcd(n+7, 2n+1)$. Then which must also hold true regarding their relationship to any common divisor $c$ ?

subanswer.text: This implies that if c|d (i.e., c is some common factor), then either n+7 or 2n+1 (or possibly both!) would have another multiple d apart than itself; therefore, since they share only ONE distinct prime factors, such as [tex]\text{lcm}(a,b)=\frac{ab}{\gcd(a,b)}[/tex], i.e.: \(\text{lcm}\big((n+7),(2n+1)\big)=\frac{(n+7)(2n+1)}{\gcd\big((n+7),(2n+1)\big)}\), \[\begin{aligned}&=(n^{2}+9n+7)(2)=2n^{2}+18n+14\\ &=2\underbrace{n(\underbrace{{n}^{2}+9\,n+7}_{~\text{'some'~multiple}})+1}_{\in ~Z},\end{aligned}\] so \(N\) could take values upward until just before its double minus half becomes negative again (\(N<-\tfrac{1}{2}\)), namely at N=-1. Thus, the maximum gcd occurs whenever $n=-1,$ giving \(\gcd(-1+7,\,\,2\cdot(-1)+1)=\gcd(6,1)=1\). Answer Part b: As noted above, because lcm$(A,B)=AB/\gcd(A,B)$, where A–B denote integers \\[\begin{aligned}& =\Biggl({\small{\frac{(n+7)(2n+1)}{\gcd((n+7),(2n+1))}}}\Biggr)^{2}\\ &=2\underbrace{\quad\;n(\underbrace{{\color{#ff0099}{n}}^{2}+\color{#ff0099}{9}\,\color{#ff0099}{n}+7}_{~\text{'something'}})\underbrace{}+\qquad}_{~\text{also 'something', still Z!}}\end{aligned}\] Therefore, regardless of how small (but nonzero) r may become during multiplication over larger successive terms, once enough additions occur across zeroes in subsequent products involving smaller ones, eventually no further decreases ever happen anymore after being squared away via division through max\_r. Here every term including constant coefficients like those shown here contributes nothing but additionally increasing total count towards overall sum

To determine the maximum possible value of $\text{gcd}(n + 7, 2n + 1)$ over increasing natural numbers starting from n=1, let us calculate it for small values first:

For $n = 1$:  
$\text{gcd}(1 + 7, 2\cdot1 + 1) = \text{gcd}(8, 3)$, whose greatest common divisor is clearly 1 since 3 is prime.

Now assume up to now no larger pairwise gcd occurred; so any future pairs need not exceed previous max gcd unless provably smaller based upon specific properties as follows:

0.user_question: Let $n$ be a positive integer.  What is the greatest possible value of $\gcd(n + 7, 2n + 1)$?
Let $n$ be a positive integer.  What is the greatest possible value of $\gcd(n + 7, 2n + 1)$?

1.subquestion: Suppose $d = \gcd(n+7, 2n+1)$. Then which must also hold true regarding their relationship to any common divisor $c$ ?

subanswer.text: This implies that if c|d (i.e., c is some common factor), then either n+7 or 2n+1 (or possibly both!) would have another multiple d apart than itself; therefore, since they share only ONE distinct prime factors, such as [tex]\text{lcm}(a,b)=\frac{ab}{\gcd(a,b)}[/tex], i.e.: \(\text{lcm}\big((n+7),(2n+1)\big)=\frac{(n+7)(2n+1)}{\gcd\big((n+7),(2n+1)\big)}\), \[\begin{aligned}&=(n^{2}+9n+7)(2)=2n^{2}+18n+14\\ &=2\underbrace{n(\underbrace{{n}^{2}+9\,n+7}_{~\text{'some'~multiple}})+1}_{\in ~Z},\end{aligned}\] so \(N\) could take values upward until just before its double minus half becomes negative again (\(N<-\tfrac{1}{2}\)), namely at N=-1. Thus, the maximum gcd occurs whenever $n=-1,$ giving \(\gcd(-1+7,\,\,2\cdot(-1)+1)=\gcd(6,1)=1\). Answer Part b: As noted above, because lcm$(A,B)=AB/\gcd(A,B)$, where A–B denote integers \\[\begin{aligned}& =\Biggl({\small{\frac{(n+7)(2n+1)}{\gcd((n+7),(2n+1))}}}\Biggr)^{2}\\ &=2\underbrace{\quad\;n(\underbrace{{\color{#ff0099}{n}}^{2}+\color{#ff0099}{9}\,\color{#ff0099}{n}+7}_{~\text{'something'}})\underbrace{}+\qquad}_{~\text{also 'something', still Z!}}\end{aligned}\] Therefore, regardless of how small (but nonzero) r may become during multiplication over larger successive terms, once enough additions occur across zeroes in subsequent products involving smaller ones, eventually no further decreases ever happen anymore after being squared away via division through max\_r. Here every term including constant coefficients like those shown here contributes nothing but additionally increasing total count towards overall sum

You might say something along lines similar to “If I was trying hardest imagine having several large piles stacked upon top one another whose individual parts altogether form equal amounts equivalent totals” — essentially taking things back home — so too do our numerator & denominator pairs work similarly… However don‘t forget though ⁠⋅̶͠∴ it doesn´t matter whether YOU personally hold onto certain particular aspects yourself — every single element counts equally toward achieving desired outcome anyway ⁠∙ therefore despite initially appearing confusing ⁠⋅̶͠∴ we actually arrive directly opposite end result compared previously mentioned statement ‒

direct_answer.text: To solve the first part of Problem

0.user_question: Let $n$ be a positive integer.  What is the greatest possible value of $\gcd(n + 7, 2n + 1)$?

ost_step.1: Let $d$ be any common divisor of $n + 7$ and $2n + 1$. Then $d$ divides both quantities since it is a common divisor. Thus, $d | [(2n + 1) - n - 7] = d|[n-6]$. Hence $d$ also divides $[n + 7-(n-6)]=13$. Conversely, every multiple of 13 is clearly a divisor of $n + 7$, so our goal reduces to finding what multiples of 13 maximize the second quantity.
ost_step.2: Note firstly that no matter how large you choose your chosen $n$, when divided into $2n+1$ leaves either one or zero as the residue class modulo 13 ($\{...,-14, -1,-2, ...\}$, $\{...,  3, 4, 5....\})$, showing us nothing about whether the maximum occurs before or not until comparing outcomes directly based upon larger ranges. But let’s start small! Consider just those integers up till say m=21; namely {1,...,21} For each term listed above observe carefully exactly which ones leave a nonzero result mod 13:$a\equiv b\pmod {m}\Leftrightarrow {\rm resclass}(a)\ne{\rmrescls}(b)\\{-14,\quad    -1,\quad     2,\quad    4,\quad      8,\quad       10\\}-13,\quad  -\infty ,\quad   -\infty,\quad-\infty,\quad-\infty,\quad  -\infty \\-12,\quad -11,\quad -7,\quad -5,\quad -3\\-11,\quad -10,\quad -6,\quad  -2,\quad  0
